message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest palmar fibromatosis, also known as Dupuytren's contracture. The skin puckering and painless palmar nodules are characteristic of this condition. Ganglion cysts usually present as soft tissue masses and do not cause limited hand mobility. Ulnar nerve lesions typically cause numbness and weakness in the hand, but not limited mobility of specific digits. Tenosynovitis may cause limited movement, but usually involves pain and swelling, which are not mentioned in the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of limited mobility of right hand with skin puckering near proximal flexor crease and painless palmar nodules adjacent to the distal palmar crease are consistent with palmar fibromatosis, also known as Dupuytren’s contracture. Other options such as ganglion cyst and tenosynovitis would not cause these specific findings. Ulnar nerve lesion could cause hand dysfunction, but it would present differently.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The skin puckering, painless palmar nodules, and limited mobility of the 4th and 5th digits suggest palmar fibromatosis, also known as Dupuytren’s contracture. The patient’s family history also supports this diagnosis. Ganglion cyst usually presents as a painless mass and does not cause limited mobility of fingers. Ulnar nerve lesion would cause numbness and weakness in the hand, but not specifically limited extension of the 4th and 5th digits. Tenosynovitis may cause swelling and pain but does not usually progress to limited mobility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of limited mobility of the right hand, skin puckering near the proximal flexor crease with painless palmer nodules adjacent to the distal palmar crease, and a family history of similar symptoms suggest Palmar fibromatosis (also known as Dupuytren's Contracture) as the most likely underlying mechanism. Ganglion cyst, ulnar nerve lesion, and tenosynovitis may cause similar symptoms but do not match the specific presentation described in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, smoking, and alcohol use increases the risk of palmar fibromatosis (Dupuytren’s contracture). The skin puckering and painless palmar nodules adjacent to the distal palmar crease are characteristic of palmar fibromatosis. Limited mobility of the right hand suggests that the nodules may be affecting the tendons or ligaments, causing contractures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest palmar fibromatosis or Dupuytren's contracture. This is a condition in which the connective tissue in the palm of the hand thickens and forms nodules, causing the fingers to slowly curl inward. Family history and smoking are risk factors for this condition, and metformin is not known to cause this condition. Ganglion cyst can cause pain and swelling, but it is not typically associated with limited mobility of the fingers. Ulnar nerve lesion and tenosynovitis can also cause limited finger mobility, but they would not present with skin puckering and nodules.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings indicate palmar fibromatosis, also known as Dupuytren's contracture. The nodules and skin puckering are characteristic of this condition, and it is common in people with a family history and those who have worked with their hands for many years. Ganglion cysts may cause swelling and tenderness but do not typically cause limited mobility of the fingers. Ulnar nerve lesions may cause weakness or numbness but would not cause the specific symptoms noted here. Tenosynovitis is inflammation of the tendon sheath and may cause pain and swelling but would not cause the limited extension of the fingers described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms match those of palmar fibromatosis, also known as Dupuytren's contracture. The skin puckering and painless nodules along the palmar surface of the hand, along with limited finger extension, are characteristic of this condition. The risk factors and family history provided in the question further support this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings are classic for palmar fibromatosis, also known as Dupuytren's contracture. It is a condition where the palmar fascia thickens and forms nodules, which can lead to limited joint mobility. It is commonly seen in patients with a family history, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and those with a history of manual work or smoking. Ganglion cysts usually occur over joints and are not associated with limited joint mobility. Ulnar nerve lesions typically cause weakness or numbness in the affected hand. Tenosynovitis may cause tenderness, swelling, and pain over the affected tendons but do not cause limited joint mobility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest palmar fibromatosis, also known as Dupuytren's contracture. It is a condition where the palmar fascia thickens and contracts, leading to flexion deformities of the fingers. History of the patient's father having similar symptoms and being treated surgically also supports this diagnosis. Ganglion cysts typically present as masses and do not cause flexion deformities. Ulnar nerve lesion would cause weakness and numbness in the hand but not limited extension of fingers. Tenosynovitis would cause pain and swelling around the affected tendons but not limited extension of fingers.
